column2: Overall, are you finding being furloughed a positive experience?
column3: That's great to hear, can you tell me why you're enjoying it?
column4: Are you now working as part of a scaled back team, whilst your colleagues are furloughed?
column5: Overall, are you finding being part of scaled-back, caretaker team a positive experience?
column6: I'm sorry to hear that, can you tell me why it's not a positive experience?
column7: Have you learned anything new about yourself?
column8: What would help you most right now?
column9: That's really good to hear, why do you think that is?

column3: I‚Äôm feel like I now have the time to invest in myself. I‚Äôm being more active, I‚Äôve started a diary, I‚Äôm doing more house renovations - I felt, while I was still working full time, that I didn‚Äôt have the time or motivation to do any of those things.
column7: I enjoy being at home more than I thought.

column3: I have lots of creative pursuits that I often don't have time for, so this is a really good opportunity for me to focus on those. It's also great to slow down though it is still hard to feel like you've lost a bit of purpose in the day to day.
column7: I'm definitely obsessively productive! If I have a down day, which there have been a few, I'm really hard on myself. I like to be productive and proactive most of the time and don't allow myself days where I'm not like that. Also I'm pretty terrible at making soup.

column6: Feeling very useless and often times even worthless. I'm childless and my husband is a key worker, so at times I am feeling very lonely and emotional. There are good days, when I focus on something and put my soul into it. Things I've not been able to do during work. There are bad days when I get updates at work and feel left out or vulnerable in that the business are functioning without me. It has been an emotional roller coaster full of anxiety.
column8: Hmmm...good question. I've been asking myself that. I think finding a purpose or a project that makes me feel valued again would help. I've signed up to run my community's Covid-19 facebook page (it was stale, not informative and not functional) so that's a stsrt. Yes I can work on myself, learn a new language, etc....but I really need to feel part of a greater cause to get my mojo back.

column3: I have more time to study, I am able to spend valuable time with my family and to get jobs done around the house that I never have time for
column7: Yes I do need structure, so I have to plan each day. Even if it‚Äôs simple things like walk the dog or clean the bathroom. It keeps me focused I have found that to just do nothing affects my state of mind and I get down and sometimes tearful.

column3:
Recently moved house so I am very busy. I am not sure how I would feel if I wasn‚Äôt busy.
I really miss my job and routine however
column7: I took things for granted and can be impatient. I need to learn to relax and take everything in my stride and be patient

column3:
I'm looking at the positives, and this is bonus time that i that it's giving me time that I wouldn't usually have time for: jobs around the house, extra exercise, reading, signing up for a course.
It probably helps that I feel informed from HX about the work situation (as much as they can)
column7: Not as yet

column6: I feel without purpose. Disappointed not to be useful enough to keep. Also it‚Äôs daunting with no end date to all of this.
column8: Something real to focus on, something to dampen my anxiety.

column3: I‚Äôm able to stay safe and keep others safe. Given the situation it‚Äôs positive.
column7: Not yet.

column9: I feel kept in the loop with all areas of the caretaker team. There is full transparency across the leadership team and Im getting all the support I need

column3: Although I have rated this as a positive experience I would like to add that I am still very concerned for our families health, especially our parents as some fall into the vulnerable category.   Both myself and my husband are concerned for our employers and jobs etc too.  But aside from this I am really enjoying being home, I am lucky to have a lovely garden which now looks so neat and tidy, I have planted seeds, made bread, all sorts of cakes and completed chores that I never get around to doing!  My stress levels have disappeared and I am generally happier with not having to rush everywhere trying to cram everything into a short space of time.  It has also helped that we have had amazing weather of course :)
column7: I don't think so, I still get up early and make sure I do things each day as I like to feel I have achieved something, instead of wasting the day.  And let's just say that I am definitely the more organised one out of myself and my husband!

column9: Have purpose and am making a difference

column3: I have two young children so being able to 100% concentrate on them is very important
column7: I have learnt to appreciate the small things again, i.e. wildlife, walking and appreciating the countryside. Realising you don't need to spend a lot of money to make lasting memories

column3: The best part is spending all this time with my children!  I hadn't really noticed or appreciated until this week what beautiful, curious, loving & funny young people they are growing into.  I'm so grateful for this time I have with them & we have our health too.
column7: I've learnt to slow down!  No need to do everything at 100 miles an hour and love it

column3: Being able to spend more time as a family, whilst having the peace of mind that my role in the business is still secure and financially I am still earning
column7: I have learnt how to slow down and appreciate the small things in life more!

column6: Uncertainty, lack of routine and purpose
column8: Something to help give me purpose

column6: I miss working, day to day interactions with people and feeling that I am doing something useful.  It is also a great distraction, when you don't have that distraction all you have are your thoughts, which are not always positive.
column8: I am going to try and see if i can get a second job whilst on furlough or volunteer, it is more tricky as I have youngish children.

column3: More quality time for life, family, home improvements, self care
column7: Not yet, feels more like a healthy life reset at this point

column3: Having a little bit of downtime.  I am sure this will wear off after . a while though
column7: That I get cabin fever quite easily.  And that my cooking is not as terrible as I thought!

column9: The members of the Multi Channel Team that are in (10 of us, rather than around 30) are working closely together and doing group calls regularly to stay in touch. We are good at being self sufficient and supporting one another but Ricky Dore is also doing a great job keeping us in the loop with changes etc.
Everyone working well together and now everything is centralised its easier to focus on the top priorities.

column3: I would say my feelings are mixed about furloughing as there are some positive and negative aspects for me. On the negative side, I am feeling a bit frustrated about not being able to continue with the projects I was working on before furlough and am missing the team too. I am very lucky to work in a job that I love so I am missing that a lot. On the plus side, I am enjoying have a lot more time with my children which I don't usually have. We are all very busy with work and for the kids, school work and activities, and we have now found that we have been able to slow down and are really enjoying our time together. I have also found more time to work on my side projects such as blog writing and building my website to help others learn data science. I am also feeling much healthier having more time for exercise and to cook very nutritious meals.
column7: I have learned that I tend to fill my time too much and leave very little room for relaxed leisure time.

column9: Working with a team member who has the opposite skills set yet the same thought process makes it quite straight forward to get tasks done in an efficient way.

column6: Unsettled. Knowing there are people and work and you are not needed. Keeping an eye on things from a distance means you don‚Äôt relax.
column8: Can‚Äôt think of anything anyone can do to help!

column3: It's more that I've decided to make the most of it and so I'm playing board games with my kids, doing regular exercise, reading, baking etc.  Prior to that I was worrying about my colleagues, feeling guilty for 'being off', worried about long term future etc and it was a downward spiral that was making my family anxious too.  So together we agreed not to worry about screen time or anything like that (was causing arguments) as long as we spend at least an hour together every evening, not including dinner which we are also ensuring we do together, in the dining room, no phones or other distractions.
column7: I thought I always had to be busy - if I sat down for too long I felt guilty, now I realise if I'm not 'busy' all the time I'm not a bad person, I'm not setting my kids a bad example, the world WILL keep turning and actually I deserve it.

column3: Time spent with family, getting jobs done around the house, slight mental break from being a fulltime working parent
column7: I have more patience with the kids than I usually do when working full time so need to bring that in when things get back to normal

column3: Having the extra time with family plus time to invest extra time in my learning
column7: I tend to do better when I have a routine.

column3: initially I felt quite upset at prospect as would be cut off from my role..but I quickly adjusted and now viewing it as a positive opportunity. Its given me time to pause..time for family..time for creativity that I would never normally have. it's made me realise how much of my life is dominated by work. I'm looking forward to self develop too though through some online courses.
column7: not really..I'm generally very positive anyway and adapt well

column3: Time with my children and partner that I otherwise wouldn't have got to spend with them
column7: That I need to chill out, stop sweating the small stuff and embrace the chaos

column3: In these tough times it is very comforting to know I still have a steady income. It significantly reduces the negative impact of coronavirus. Furthermore, I am taking the time to finish writing a book I have been working on for a while, which I'm really enjoying.
column7: I am very much a grin and bear it person! I also need a semblance of routine to stay happy.

column3: Time to spend with my kids ( although they do my head in at times!), time to get jobs done around the house and garden because we usually spend weekends as family time, and time to reflect and think without the pressure and stress i usually put on myself about work.
column7: I need to stop worrying so much about work, and I‚Äôm starting to realise that I need to let mum guilt go, it‚Äôs good for my younger one to have time in a childminder environment

column3: Nice to have a significant block of time to spend on side projects that would otherwise be squeezed into evenings and weekends.
column7: I'm an introvert but I miss my work friends and the structure that work brings.

column6: I have worked since my 16th birthday and I‚Äôm turning 40 this year and have never had more than 2 weeks off. Relaxing is not something I do and although I have filled time with volunteering there‚Äôs lots of free time. As a sufferer of anxiety free time equals time to think. All I think about is redundancy, I am a higher earner vs most and although I believe I am an asset I can also be seen as a decent cost saving. All I want it to be contributing to the team and not sitting on the sidelines, not knowing is one of the hardest things.
column8: It is all Unknown and what I want is clarity and job security, two things that can not be given. I am hoping for more charity work to keep me and my mind busy.

column9: We are a tight knit team so we see our work as vital to support our business ready to welcome back our furloughed colleagues but we also see their self-sacrifice in accepting furlough equally as important

column3: Read around a subject called ‚Äúpattern interrupt‚Äù. Basically using it to form new habits that are positive for me post Corona.
column7: I really cared about my employment to define me. I was on auto pilot putting my job first without question. I didn‚Äôt appreciate how valued I was by others

column3: Time to breathe. Time to fix some mental and physical health issues that have been bothering me. Time to enjoy my other passions and hobbies
column7: I‚Äôve suffered badly over past few years with anxiety, spent a lot of time worrying about worst case scenarios. This is pretty high up there on worst case scenarios but I‚Äôm surviving. So what else do I not need to fear.

column6: The day to day is okay but being trapped inside is frustrating. There are a lot of good things I have time for now which is great. If I knew for sure when things would end and if our jobs would be safe I could be less anxious and enjoy it slightly more.
column8: Probably speaking to a therapist honestly.

column3: I wouldn‚Äôt say, I‚Äôm enjoying it; I think the question asked if I was finding it a positive experience. I‚Äôm finding it a positive experience because I‚Äôm staying close to my team, I‚Äôm getting fitter, I‚Äôm practicing skills I otherwise neglect (like languages and music) and I‚Äôm being mindful.
column7: I‚Äôve learned that I want to ride the storm with my employer rather than jump ship - I think that‚Äôs because I really like the people, culture and product.

column6: Very long hours, high stress. Probably better for my mental health to be ignorant of the commercial reality
column8: A very high level view of possible exit plans from government. Too many unknown unknowns right now. Will help business give an idea to our teams of what this might look like in months ahead.

column3: Takes pressure off while the children are off school. I can focus on their well being more. At a time when the world is in such huge upheaval I was finding it hard to focus on work.
column7: I can stay indoors longer than I thought I could (after just finishing a 2 week self isolation period!). Usually I get cabin fever and can only stay in the house for a day before I need to go out somewhere!

column6: I thrive on face-to-face interaction which I miss enormously. Technology is great but doesn't replace sitting with those you care about. I do enjoy the fact that I am able to be front-line helping people across our business during  this time and helping give them some comfort.
column8: We're all in the same boat - it's a case of waiting things out.

column6: I've struggled with my mental health as a result of having more time to think.
column8: Social interaction in whatever form it comes in and a project to work on (having a small child makes it hard to do either of the above to the right scale for my mental health)

column3: From a working perspective, being furloughed is great because it alleviates some concerns for the next few months, knowing that it is helping to put the business in a strong position for when this crisis passes, while still being paid almost a full salary. From a personal perspective, I'm finding it a bit tougher.
column7: That I'm not very good at being completely unstructured!

column3: Redecorating the house, homeschooling the kids, cooking together, everything is just bringing the family closer together
column7: I‚Äôm not as strong as I think and if the head of the house was measured on strength, then the kids are in charge!

column6: As there is so much work to do it's been a very draining experience, and I also think it's going to cause rifts in the team when we do eventually get back to normality as over half the team have been furloughed.
column8: Nothing really can be done we just need to get on with it. :(

column3: Taking advantage of the down time to be productive and appreciate the home we work hard for
column7: That although I have plenty of tasks, I struggle more than I thought without structure

column3: When would you ever get the chance to take time out and still be paid.  I‚Äôm working through a list of jobs that have been driving me crazy for months/years.  Enjoying being outside in the garden and spending time with my family
column7: I‚Äôve always quite enjoyed my own company.  But feel I make a plan for the day so I still have routine.  Learning to be more patient in the current circumstances to

column9: I still have work-related things to focus my time on.

column3: I am spending time on my personal development. I am also spending more time cooking and working out at home.
column7: I'm surprised I'm still happy being stuck at home for so long, if these were normal times I would be pushing to get out and about and get fresh air.

column9: It‚Äôs nice to be essential

column3: Enjoying quality time with my son, being able to slow down and do things that I never have time for.
column7: No

column6: There are many positives especially spending more time with a young family but also feels there is time to make a positive impact to the business that might be missed.
column8:
A crystal ball :-)

I could relax a lot more if I knew that business would return to normal 'x' months after restrictions start to lift. Everyone is in the same boat but the worry is the financial support for workers will end before normality returns

column3: Spending the with my family and taking time to complete projects around the house. Also taking time to cook from scratch and do exercise. Just getting my life back after a long time of intensive work.
column7: Not really

column3: It's given me some time to improve my skill to help the business when I return
column7: I enjoy working and enjoy coding

column6: Loss of drive after being rejected
column8: Not having a toddler, not feeling constantly guilty, being able to contribute

column6: Knowing that my employer cannot sustain and on top of farlough they cannot contribute any sum from their side to provide extra financial support, which could be of a great help than just being on minimum pay
column8: Stay positive and keep the lights on

column3: I now have time to start and complete all the jobs that I previously didn‚Äôt have time for but were looming over me. Once the jobs are done there will be a bit less stress when I go back to work
column7: That I need a mixture of time to myself and time being social. The ratio between the two changes from time to time but I definitely need both in my life

column6: It feels that the HMRC rules create unfairness and separatism at an extreme between those that work and those that are furloughed.  It seems the rules are based on a cynical attempt to prevent businesses operating fraudulently rather than what the human beings need in terms of purposefulness and the social side of work.
column8: To allow those that are furloughed to work on innovation, creative projects that can help create a better future

column3: It gives me a chance to do things I‚Äôve never had enough time for when working full time
column7: I‚Äôve learnt that I like to be busy and have a sense of purpose on a day to day basis. It has made me realise how much I miss being surrounded by people and working with people I wouldn‚Äôt usually be around

column3: Because I am enjoying the benefits if the lovely weather and spending time with my little boy.
column7: I eat a lot of snacks !! I enjoy doing daily exercise outdoors.

column3: I don't have the anxiety and stress about making sure I'm doing enough hours and having the mental capacity of working whilst balancing full time childcare of a 2 year old.
column7: I need hobbies! Need to be better at entertaining myself e.g. sewing, exercise etc

column3: Its put life in perspective, its always rush rush, its great taking the time to do odd jobs and enjoy the sunshine.
column7: I like sitting in a quiet room not having to talk to anyone...

column3: I‚Äôve been able to give our children my full attention and help guide them through this worrying time.
column7:
Yes, I‚Äôve learnt our family unit is very comfortable together 24/7. 
I have learnt I‚Äôm content in my own skin and that I have missed the time to read, watch and listen to those around me.
I have recognised the news effects me in a negative way by making me feel anxious and angry so have taken measures to restrict the amount of time  I attend to it.

column9: Sharp focus, hand picked team. Cuts out the noise

column3: Able to do things I normally don't have time to do; catching up jobs around the house but also learning French, reading books, enjoying my garden.
column7: Probably nothing I don't already know - I enjoy isolation and my own company. I find it hard to let go completely of work. I find it very hard to sit and do nothing.

column3: It‚Äôs not that I‚Äôm enjoying it, it‚Äôs because I feel safer at home. I‚Äôve been able to do some jobs at home that have not had time for.
column7: I miss structure and the daily work routine, my body clock all over the place, I miss brain work and being busy. I have no will power with food being so available. I can‚Äôt focus when trying to learn a new skill.

column9: Getting a chance to work directly with people at all levels of the business rather going through layers of management.  Quick decision making.

column6: Loss of colleagues - different dynamic - all working from home full time - new relationships to build online - much busier ... when it‚Äôs all said and done it‚Äôs much better than than the alternative that may, could have been.
column8: Lottery win! Nothing really we are all in it together everyone is going through this - there is no wrong or right way. It‚Äôs a brand new way of being!

column9: Still have a sense of purpose and a need to keep the operation running, especially during this time.

column6: Loss of progression, was due a promotion in April, and pay (only on 80%}
column8: Job security

column6: As a selected member of the team along with 3 others from a team of 8 I can‚Äôt help but wonder if I was selected as I am only a year in with the employer so will be easier and cheaper for the organisation to be made redundant with once government furlough payments are no longer available to my employer
column8: Honest communication from my line manager

column6: Need something to do. Lack of work is driving me insane. Need mental stimulation. Also don't enjoy being home all day with kids. Long to get back to normal.
column8: Finding something to fill the work gap.

column6: Because there is 10x more work than people, and I'm not superhuman. The pressure to do well is insane.
column8: More people.

column3:
I completely trust my company in doing the best and the right thing. I know there is an end point (hopefully). 
In my 33 year travel career I have never been gifted an opportunity to have ‚Äútime away‚Äù so I‚Äôm looking at it as a positive and filling that time with everything I‚Äôve wanted to do. From household jobs to new skills and study. I‚Äôve enrolled with Open University to take their free courses, I‚Äôm learning how to code, which is totally alien to me but wanted to push my boundaries and do something opposite to who I am. I‚Äôm
Grateful for the ‚Äúreset‚Äù and back to basics and nature. Walking with the dog and being at home has been a wonderful experience so far.
column7: That I‚Äôm ok being alone in the human sense and I want for nothing as I have abundance

column3: I feel positive because I feel lucky to have not lost my job. I'm finding coping mentally hard without work...it would be a better time if I still had work to fill my day (WFH)
column7: No

column3: I have more time for self-development which I often don't have when working. I'm doing things I don't usually have time for like gardening, reading, cooking & doing washing! I'm appreciating the world and the people around me more.
column7: Given the uncertainty around the world and around jobs right now I would expect to be feeling more concerned or anxious than I am. This may come later as things change but right now I'm seeing this as an opportunity to step back and slow down.

column6: I miss working, I love working for HX and love my job so much, it feels like my purpose has been interupted, its not overall a negative experience and keeping in touch with the teams is helping by doing quizes and fun activities remotely but it has made me realise how much i strive to achieve when at work and im trying to put that attitude to good use at home, its just a bit early on in the process
column8: more remote connections, book clubs, podcast meet ups, netflix parties, games, quizes, anything to look forward to and keep my mind occupied

column9: I feel appreciative to be perceived as a vital part of the team and by working I feel like I still add value and have a sense of purpose. I‚Äòm sure I would find positives if I was furloughed too as I have planned on learning some new things during this time which have interested me (e.g a few weeks back I bought a book to learn how to code). It‚Äôs great to continue having some form of a routine by working and it breaks the days up so I‚Äôm always keeping my mind occupied. I‚Äôm also feeling very thankful for my team, we all still communicate on a personal level every day and even have virtual group chats to check in on each other and a quiz night each week hosted in turns (online of course!). As much as this has turned normal life completely upside down, I‚Äôm missing my family like you wouldn‚Äôt believe and I worry for them all.. I‚Äôd like to see this experience as an opportunity. If you‚Äôre working you have an opportunity to make a difference, to provide support wherever needed and be part of something special. If you‚Äôre furloughed you have an opportunity to learn something new, take the time to do something you‚Äôve been putting off, or make precious memories with your family. Either way it‚Äôs time we won‚Äôt get back so I plan on spending it wisely!
Laser focus, good communication

column6: Why would it be ?
column8: The arrival of benevolent aliens

column9: There is a camaraderie with those working albeit remotely to get through this for the good of all.  We are involving the furloughed in our team as much as we can at the same time

column3: I get to spend more time with my family
column7: Nothing yet. Only a week on though.

column6: Keeping busy is really challenging, whilst also living alone. It‚Äôs proving difficult mentally and finically.
column8: Work would be ideal, something to keep busy during the week

column9: Some sort of routine and the feeling of being able to help

column3: Getting items done that I wouldn‚Äôt normally and also knowing that it is helping the company I work for
column7: I can live without work - something I thought I couldn‚Äôt before

column9: Messages of thanks and support from top team

column8: The grant offered by the government is only availa me for business rate payers. This does not help home office set ups. It would be good of this could be addressed somehow.

column3: Getting paid most of my wage and being at home safe looking after my daughter
column7: How important spending time with my daughter is

column3: Feel grateful that I have a boss willing to pay me and I‚Äôll have a job to go back to and spending time with my family doing things at home.
column7: I love going to work and having a routine

column3: Time to do other jobs
column7: Yes I can adapt to change and learn from it

column8: To know whether I will get a full wage whilst our office is closed

column3: Because my wife and I are finding plenty to do around the house both together and individually. We are enjoying each other‚Äôs company. For once time, or a lack of it, isn‚Äôt an issue.
column7: That I could really enjoy retirement.

column3: Although being stuck at home is a little tedious as I like to get out, its given me and my family a time to reflect, get lots of things done around the house in terms of deep cleans and diy projects that have been on hold. Mentally with me and my partners anxiety it has been tough as routines are out of the window and these supply a good source of structure which generally keep us sane. There has been opportunities for voluntary work, however with my partners anxiety around sickness, this would make things worse at home from a mental health point of view. On the whole though, its taught us to communicate more with people we care for and love, where normally this is something we would probably take for granted and not do as much. For me personally a good opportunity to focus on my health, losing weight and improving my mobility with exercise, which s far is going very well.
column7: Ive learnt that I can do anything if I need to, its having the self motivation. I have discovered more of this while being off and has helped me drive to get things done that I have been putting off for a while such as home projects and personal improvement projects regarding my health. I feel more positive and feel I have some improved clarity about my self worth and belief and can use this to move forward.

column6: I was one of only two people to be furloughed in the entire company.
column8: Help finding a new job

column6: I work on my customers site and they are very slow to communicate their strategy with creating unease in our caretaker team
column8: A little understanding and better communication from our client

column6: fighting for survival, increased pessimism, company owners desperate/emotional, unsure as to what the future looks like
column8: a sabbatical to spend more time with my partner

column9: It feels as if you‚Äôre being shown recognition for your hard work and commitment. I also believe it is a great time to  reflect as it can get rather lonely.

column3: I am playing with my kids every day and getting paid for it. It's lovely
column7: Slightly curious whether I want to ever come back or just run a tiny school forever but I guess my kids will outgrow my amateur educational attempts pretty soon

column3: Quality time with hubby and having time to catch up with odd jobs, and seem to speak more regularly to family on phone than we did face to face before
column7: Given time off work has allowed me to do more for others. I recognise myself as a more generous person who wants to help the community, something I hadn‚Äôt ever contemplated before.

column7: I have learnt that keeping my mind and body active helps when dealing with worrying times and it‚Äôs somthing I now make sure happens everyday

column3: More with husband and kids, saving ¬£

column3: I recently moved into my first house, so I‚Äôm getting ample time to truly enjoy it!
column7: I have been surprised to learn that I am a lot more patient than I think I am; I am also able to ‚Äúgo with the flow‚Äù more than I thought. I think because we don‚Äôt have a choice, there‚Äôs no point in resisting against the current situation. You just have to ride with it.

column9: It‚Äôs encouraging to be part of the team working to keep the company going so that there are jobs for people to return to, it makes me more motivated to work harder as I feel I‚Äôm doing it for all those on furlough.

column6:
I would say I was indifferent. Short term I see the immediate value as positive. Able to look after my girls whilst my partner is a key worker. I see the essential support it gives the business which is the most important part. 
Negatively however I have two parts. I like to be mentally stimulated and work with teams I enjoy what I do even when it‚Äôs at the most challenging points. Whilst it‚Äôs only two weeks in, the prospect of this continuing makes me feel uneasy. 
Also I ask the question of myself - ‚ÄòI was not essential‚Äô. Whilst it‚Äôs totally understandable and I was involved in the process, I still ask myself should I have done more in my role to be ‚Äòessential‚Äô previously and secondly what does that mean for the medium to more long term for me and my team given the looming economic downturn. 
I have time to think at points when I‚Äôm not teaching the kids or stopping them fighting - I think about the Job and company I really love but am I or many at risk staying in the sector we are in.
column8: There isn‚Äôt anything to be honest, the communication has been very good from the business and there are some fantastic leaders doing some terrific work. I feel a little guilty or conflicted that I‚Äôm not part of it or couldn‚Äôt contribute more at the moment.

column9: It was a close call! There is a lot more work to do, but things 'matter' more, so I feel like I'm making more of a difference. The addition of the extra work (and the lockdown) have thrown my work/life balance out of whack and I'm definitely under more stress, but overall slightly more positive than negative

column3: We moved house at the start of lockdown (extremely stressful) so the time to settle into our new place and look after our two lovely little ones has been quite well timed for us. I do appreciate that this is happening within a tragic wider context and am fully cognisant of the implications for Holiday Extras, but understand and support the actions of the management and have faith that the company will emerge strongly after all this passes.
column7: No

column3: I got an opportunity to work on my own projects, learn and be a bit more relaxed than on normal workdays.
column7: I can make decent pot desserts.

column3: I wouldn't say I'm enjoying it, but the experience is, on balance, positive. Time to learn to skills and focus on 'me' is helpful, but less money + job uncertainty is a constant worry which negates any real enjoyment of the time
column7: Apparently I love to work!

column3: more time for self development and exploring other ventures/new hobbies
column7: yes, taking time out helps to reflect

column6: I enjoy working so it‚Äôs hard to be told you cannot work.

My employer has still not been clear weather a furlough is possible for me. I have not signed any papers. Everything is up in the air. If not furloughed I am made redundant. They made me redundant before the furlough was a thing. And now I wait...

column3: m

column3: Spending more quality time with the kids, plus having the time to pick up all the things I have put off (such as finishing a book I have been trying to read for the past couple of months!)
column7: After furlough I need to work on balancing things a bit more. It's a shame its taken something like this to show how unbalanced my life is / was

column9: It's great to still be involved in the business and be part of a small caretaking team. I'm getting involved in things that wouldn't normally be part of my day to day role and I feel trusted by the business. It's also great to keep busy and the days are whizzing by!

column3: learning new things, spending time with children
column7: don't think so

column9:
Its a bit of yes and no. No because I miss those who are furloughed. 
But yes because I'm proud (and prefer) to keep working to try and keep the company afloat and try and retain / gain back money from customers.

column3: Good to take some time out, learn some new things and get perspective on things.
column7: need to not get as stressed at work.

column3: Happy that financially will be ok for the furloughed period

column7: I need to manage my time better

column3: Initially, I wasn't feeling great about it as I really wanted to stay on and be part of the caretaker team along with my colleagues.  Seeing the effect that the virus had on the business was shocking and wanted to do what I could to help.  2 weeks in and I have started to adjust and I'm using my spare time positively
column7: Yes, I don't need to go out and spend money all the time.  This time has really allowed me to adjust and think about what really is important

column3: Having time to myself and do things I have not got the chance to do before and spend time with my family
column7: I like to run and I do not like being bored. I like to be active and to always keep learning

column3: Spending time with family and also catching up on chores.
column7: I am stronger than I thought.

column3: Opportunity to take stock of life and career position and where I want to be
column7: I am finding that I am still pretty resilient!

column9: I feel that I'm getting to speak to people I wouldn't normally get to work with and also get to hear how others are working on and what their focuses are. There are some negatives, I couldn't watch the video on workplace where people who are furloughed are having fun with their kids and family, I feel bad for saying it but I felt envious as I want to be doing that with my children. However, HX is my family and I will do what ever I can to keep us going

column6: The first time in my career I've not been working full-time, this feels like a stepping stone to redundancy rather than something temporary. CTO refers to a 6-month downturn in business revenue in an e-mail while CEO talks up summer trade, the mixed messaging creating more uncertainty if there will be redundancies to follow the furlough period..
column8: A realistic update from leadership, what will happen if things don't pick up at the end of the furlough period, can we expect short time working, layoffs or redundancies?

column7: Yes I am very adaptable

column3: I'm loving having the time and mental space to focus only on things I want to do - on hobbies, on time spent with family. It's like a glimpse into being retired!
column7: I've learned that I'm more resilient and resourceful than I thought I was.

column3: I wanted to say somewhere between yes and no... But it feels like it's the least worst solution. It's better than redundancy, and better than reduced hours. But also it's frustrating not being able to contribute much useful to anything.

Im quite luckily being in a smaller team, we have a close relationship which each other and all care about each others welfare. HX has been keeping us constantly in the loop about the situation and it is generally hard to watch Matt give his updates and seeing the affect it's having on him. We all care about the business and I want to make sure I do my part to see the whole team come back to us in June (hopefully)

column6: No purpose

column6:
I'm an extrovert so working with people and communicating with them is a huge deal for me. I'm home schooling which is great to be with my child, but I miss the day to day conversation. 

I have worked since I was 14 years old. In particular with HX for 19 years and I love the company and really hope we can get through this.
column8: take me back :)

column9: I have a reason to get up every day and it keeps my mind occupied, otherwise I would be home completely on my own. It has made the bond within the team stronger than ever. I'm very lucky to have such a supportive team.

column3: Quality time with the family.  Time to achieve things I never had the time, or energy, to achieve previously.
column7: Yes - I enjoy baking :)

column3:

I have also started some courses too to keep my mind occupied
column7: I have found that I have more patience than I thought and I can keep a motivated household from killing themselves with lots of ideas of things to do together

column9: We‚Äôre all working really hard so we can bring everyone else back sooner, so we have a common goal. We also are the hardest working bunch. It‚Äôs heads down all the time. Then when we break to convene we‚Äôre all aware of how hard each of us have been working.

column3: I've been really productive and managed to make a lot of progress on jobs and tasks I've wanted to tackle for some time.
column7: Not yet, it still feels very familiar to my usual way of life

column8: Going back to work, I‚Äôve been lucky and have been asked to come back which has helped massively!

column6: I love being active and in touch with people and love love love the job I do. Miss seeing the team, the office, the cappuccino... Feel slightly useless sat at home not being able to help at a difficult time. Not having my happy place (which work is) has thrown me into a slight depressive mode... Also the fact that a worry remains for my entire work (and private) family... about the future and the sustainability of their&my position. The 80% pay are fantastic and having the time with my children is amazing, however I find the uncertainty about the future very unsettling.
column8: Reassurance that everything is going to remain the same (post COVID19) - but thats something nobody can guarantee right now - just like a cure for the Coronavirus! column9: Focus and purpose remain

However there are days when I stop and think about the situation and start to panic about the future and whether or not I'll have a job to come back to.

column3: Apart from actually catching Covid-19 and being ill since 1st April, this furlough state makes me confident that a job will still have my name on it at the end of all this. column3:
Slowe paced living and spending more time with my partner and dog. I am really appreciating the time I spend outside on dog walks more than ever before and discovering new walks closer to home. 
Also I feel, strangely, more connected to my friends and family - my theory is there are less distractions around resulting in giving and receiving everyone's undivided attention during video call catch ups. 
Learning to find beauty in everything you had taken for granted previously.

I hope I continue to take time out to reflect and appreciate life when 'normal' returns.

column3:
After a week of working 
from home, trying to appear busy when there was clearly no work, furlough was a relief, as thoughts of redundancies where high in many of our heads. Being on furlough means I have time to learn. I've completed courses that will make me better when I return to work, and had time to dedicate to a book I'm writing, but never found the time to dedicate to before.
column7: I quickly learnt that I hate working from home, and need the regular calls I still have with my colleagues. The freelance world would not be for me!

column3: Quality time with my children and husband that I would never normally of ever had if everything was normal.
column7: Sometimes I‚Äôm not very patient but I‚Äôve learnt to be more patient and relaxed about things. At first I felt really stressed trying to juggle work and homeschool my children however being furloughed has taken that pressure off and made me be more relaxed and easy going.
